name: Production Lab
description: Laboratory experience in quantity food production and service.

name: Statics
description:
Force systems and equilibrium conditions with emphasis on engineering
problems.
prereq:
(PHY 009A C- or better or PHY 009HA C- or better); MAT 021D C- or better { can
be concurrent }

name: Topics in Literature
description:
Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not
necessarily historically. May be taught abroad.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: Intro Microbiology
description:
Essentials of microbial biology, emphasizing phylogeny, physiology, genetics,
ecology, and pathogenesis. Interactions with other microbes, humans, and the
biosphere. Uses of microbes in agriculture and biotechnology. May be taught
abroad.
prereq: (BIS 001A or BIS 002A); CHE 002B { can be concurrent }

name: Musics of the World
description:
Survey of selected art, folk, and popular music cultures from different parts
of the world. Emphasis on understanding relationship of musical style,
aesthetic principles, and performance practice to wider cultural contexts.

name: Risk: Natural Hazards
description:
Risk, prediction, prevention and response for earthquakes, volcanic eruptions,
landslides, floods, storms, fires, impacts, global warming.

name: Study Indiv Author
description:
In-depth study of an author's works; historical context; relation to
predecessors and contemporaries; critical reception; influence.

name: Intro Topics Lit & Media
description:
Study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and moving-
image media.
prereq: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); Or equivalent.

name: Introduction to History
description:
Introduction to history, its key methodologies, writing tasks, and research
practices. Examination of the development of history as an academic
discipline; ethics in historical research. Topical focus changes regularly.

name: Introduction to Ecology
description: General survey of the principles of ecology.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B
or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); Or the equivalent.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Writing: Poetry
description:
Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in
experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Chaucer: Troilus & Poems
description:
Development of the poet's artistry and ideas from his first work to his
masterpiece, "Troilus and Criseyde."
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or the equivalent.

name: Circuits I
description:
Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities
and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC
circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network
functions.

name: Nat, Regions & Other Geo
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: Earthquakes & Hazards
description:
Impact of earthquakes, tsunami, volcanoes, landslides, and floods on humans,
structures, and the environment. Discussion of the causes and effects of
disasters and catastrophes, and on prediction, preparation, and mitigation of
natural hazards.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: France Since 1815
description: France since 1815.

name: Container Media
description:
Principles of soil science and practices related to management of container
media are taught, emphasizing appropriate use of soils and amendments,
irrigation, and fertilizers.Physical and chemical properties are tested and
effects of management on crops are evaluated in the laboratory.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Reconstruction
First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Mechatronic Systems
description:
Modeling of dynamic engineering systems in various energy domains. Analysis
and design of dynamic systems. Response of linear systems. Digital computer
simulation and physical experiments.
prereq: ENG 100 C- or better; ENG 102 C- or better

name: Principles Environ Tox
description:
Principles of toxicology with a focus on environmental, industrial, and
natural chemicals. Topics include fate and effects of chemicals in organisms
and the environment, air pollutants, insecticides, aquatic toxicology,
endocrine disruptors, biomarkers and bioassays, and risk assessment.

name: Writers' Workshop
description:
Focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways
to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content for a writing
task; to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

name: 19th Cen British Novel
description:
Historically or thematically organized examination of 19th-century British
novelists, with emphasis on the historical novel, the social novel, and novels
by women: Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, Eliot, Hardy.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or the equivalent.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Seminar Literary Studies
description:
Intensive, focused study of literature at an advanced level. May be organized
by topic, author, period, movement, or genre. High participation.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Food Chem Lab
description:
Study of basic chemical and physical properties that influence the reactivity
and functional properties of components in food systems.

name: Mechanical Design
description:
Principles of mechanics applied to design. Deformation and stress analysis.
Structural integrity under static and fluctuating loads. Projects demonstrate
progression from concept to engineering analysis, with emphasis on strength
and durability.
prereq:
(ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); (ENG 104 C- or better, EME
050 C- or better { can be concurrent })

name: The Short Story
description:
The short story as a genre; its historical development, techniques, and formal
character as a literary form. European as well as American writers.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y

name: Comp In French
description:
Instruction and practice in expository writing in French, with emphasis on
organization, correct syntax, and vocabulary building.

name: U S Since 1896
description:
Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion,
research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history.
United States since 1896.

name: Lab: Early Childhood
description:
Application of theories of learning and development to interaction with
infants, toddlers, and preschoolers at Early Childhood Laboratory. Applied
skills in communication, guidance and curriculum.
prereq:
HDE 140 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140 must be
taken concurrently for first 3 units of credit; students must contact the
Center for Child & Family Studies to enroll.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Youth in Revolt
description:
American literary and cultural representations of adolescence as a time of
rebellious refusals and wild behaviors in relation to questions of gender and
sexuality, psychological states, economic pressures, racial inequality, and
methods of discipline and punishment.

name: Intro Topics in Lit
description:
Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place
or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: Elementary Hindi/Urdu I
description:
Introduction to Devanagari Script through development of all language skills
in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

name: Dsgn & Anlys Sensory Sci
description:
Methods of design and analysis for sensory food science. Experimental design
strategies. Use of taste panels and consumer testing. Data analysis and
computation including the relative merits and limitations of parametric and
nonparametic approaches. Modifications for quality assurance.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Global Environ Change
description:
Fundamental scientific concepts underlying issues such as global warming,
pollution, and the future of nonsustainable resources presented in the context
of anthropogenic processes as well as natural forcing of paleoenvironmental
change throughout Earth's history.

name: Young Children
description:
Integration of research, theory and practice in child development, emphasizing
the role of relationships in creating a growth-promoting environment for young
children. Includes: peer relationships, emotional understanding and self
regulation, attachment, communication and school readiness.
prereq:
HDE 100A; HDE 140L { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140L
required concurrently.

name: Properties of Materials
description:
Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to
the internal structure of materials.
prereq:
(MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); (CHE 002A C- or better, PHY
009A C- or better)

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Paleobiology
description:
Evolution and ecological structure of the biosphere from the origin of life to
the present.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Public Lands Mgmt
description:
Investigation of alternative approaches to public lands management by Federal
and state agencies. Role each agency's legislation plays in determining the
range of resource allocations.

name: Intro Topics in Lit
description:
Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place
or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: Intro to Evolution
description:
General survey of the origins of biological diversity and evolutionary
mechanisms.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B
or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); STA 100 recommended.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Mil Training Skills
description:
Enhancement of student leadership performance through practical application.
Small unit military tactical operations as the basis for the student
exploration and development.
prereq: MSC 141; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: Intro Music History
description:
History of music from the late Baroque to Beethoven. Intended primarily for
majors in music.
prereq: MUS 006A { can be concurrent }; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Intro Environ Design
description:
Introduction to the role of design professionals in contributing to the built
environment at a range of scales. Introduction to basic methods used by design
professionals to evaluate, design, plan, and manage landscapes and the built
environment.

name: Intro Linguistics
description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

name: Linear Algebra Comp Lab
description: Introduction to MATLAB and its use in linear algebra.
prereq: MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C or MAT 021CH

name: Army Mngmt Systems
description:
Leadership and management, focusing on four management systems: planning,
organizing, leading and controlling. Practical methodologies for assessing
management decisions while balancing competing ethical, economic,
infrastructure and future growth trade-offs.
prereq: MSC 142; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: Primary Care Clinics
description:
Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani
Clinic. Field experience introduces students to health care delivery, patient
histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention,
diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic
laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Enrollment at the UC Davis campus; upper division
standing.

name: General Microbiology Lab
description:
Principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms.
Designed for students continuing in microbiology, genetics, or biochemistry.
prereq:
MIC 102 C or better; (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 129A); and Consent of
Instructor.

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: Mechanisms of Cell Div
description:
The molecules and mechanisms that allow eukaryotic cells to coordinate cell
growth, DNA replication, segregation of chromosomes and cell division.

name: Brazilian Samba School
description:
Practice of Brasilian music. Basic instrumental technique and repertory. Focus
on the percussion traditions of Rio de Janeiro and Bahia.

name: Bayanihan Clinic
description:
Through active participation in the medical aspects of community health
clinics, the undergraduate student gains knowledge of the organization,
administration, and problem-solving capabilities.

name: Elementary Theory
description:
Development of music writing and listening skills through the study of music
fundamentals, species counterpoint, harmony, analysis of repertory. Intended
primarily for music majors.
prereq:
MUS 002A { can be concurrent }; MUS 016A { can be concurrent }; required
concurrently.

name: Masterworks Jpn Lit
description:
Introduction to Japanese literature: readings and discussion in English of
important works from earliest times to the present.

name: Classical Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for
physical science and engineering majors. Classical mechanics.
prereq: MAT 021B or MAT 021M; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Elementary Accounting
description:
Basic concepts of accounting; interpreting and using financial statements;
understanding accounting principles.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to integral calculus and elementary differential equations via
applications to biology and medicine. Fundamental theorem of calculus,
techniques of integration including integral tables and numerical methods,
improper integrals, elementary first order differential equations,
applications in biology and medicine.
prereq:
MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better or MAT
021AH C- or better

name: Dev Psychopathology
description:
Foundational principles and current issues in developmental psychopathology,
the study of mental health problems and disorders that originate in childhood
and adolescence (e.g., disruptive behavior, mood and anxiety disorders).
prereq: (HDE 100A, HDE 100B) or PSC 140; Consent of Instructor.

name: Adv Molecular Biology
description:
Structure, expression, and regulation of eukaryotic genes. Chromosome
structure and replication; gene structure, transcription, and RNA processing;
protein synthesis and translation control; development, immune system, and
oncogenes.
prereq:
BIS 101; (BIS 102 { can be concurrent } or BIS 105 { can be concurrent } or
ABI 102 { can be concurrent }); BIS 102 or BIS 105 or ABI 102 can be
concurrent although prior completion is recommended.

name: The Chinese Revolution
description:
Analysis of China's cultural and political transformation from Confucian
empire into Communist state. Emphasis on emergence and triumph of peasant
revolutionary strategy (to 1949), with some attention to its implications for
post-revolutionary culture and politics.

name: Latin Amer Soc Rev
Real Analysis
description: Derivatives, integrals, sequences of functions, and power series.

name: Intro Abstract Math
description:
Rigorous treatment of mathematical concepts with emphasis on developing the
ability to understand abstract mathematical ideas, to read and write
mathematical concepts, and to prove theorems. Designed to serve as preparation
for the more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Open to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

name: Tutoring Math
description:
Special projects in mathematical education developing techniques for
mathematics instruction and tutoring on an individual or small group basis.

name: Internship
description: Professional field experience in landscape architecture.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Senior standing in Landscape Architecture.

name: Modern Japanese
description:
Readings in modern Japanese short stories, newspaper articles, and essays;
conversation practice based on these readings.
prereq: JPN 006 C- or better; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: Ordinary Diff Equations
Dir Group Study
description: Directed group study.

name: Intermediate Persian
description:
Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills as
well as cultural topics in intermediate Persian.

name: Classical Physics
description:
Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena,
optics.
prereq: PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D { can be concurrent }

name: Food Chem Clin Nutr
description:
Chemical and physical principles that influence functional properties,
nutrient content, safety, and sensory aspects of food. Emphasis on the
application of these concepts in clinical nutrition.
prereq:
CHE 008B C- or better or CHE 118B C- or better or CHE 128B C- or better;
concurrent with FST 100A recommended.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: Stellar Astrophysics
description:
Chemical composition, structure, energy sources and evolutionary history of
stars, with equal emphasis on both the observational data and theoretical
models, including black holes, neutron stars and white dwarfs and the
formation of substellar masses.
prereq: PHY 009A; PHY 009B; PHY 009C; PHY 009D; or Consent of Instructor.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intermed Musicianship
description:
Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight
singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and
listening analysis.
prereq:
MUS 016C; MUS 007A { can be concurrent }; Or demonstrate required proficiency
level on diagnostic exam.

name: Safavid Iran
description:
Middle Eastern history focusing on Safavid Empire (present-day Iran, Iraq,
Afghanistan, up to Georgia), beginning with the origins of the dynasty as a
powerful religious family, to the establishment of the Empire, focusing on
Social, Religious, Economic, and Political History.

name: Asian American History
description:
Historical experience of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from
the mid-19th century to the present. Migration, labor, community formation,
race relations, women and gender, popular culture.

name: Intro to Engineering
description:
Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of
engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering
fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Human Rights
description:
Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the origins, evolution, denial
and protection of Human Rights.

name: Italian Internship
description:
Participation in community service, teaching, government, and business
activities to gain work experience and to develop a better knowledge of
Italian language and culture. May be taught abroad in Italy.
prereq:
Upper division standing, consent of instructor and UC Davis program director
or chairperson of Italian Department.

name: Enzymes & Receptors
description:
Introduction to the principles of enzyme kinetics and receptor-ligand
interactions with emphasis on metabolic regulation and data analysis. Topics
include simultaneous equilibria, chemical and steady-state kinetics,
allosteric enzymes, mulitreactant systems, enzyme assays, membrane transport
and computer-assisted simulations and analyses.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Design & Build Studio
description:
Introduction to the spatial design and construction of small-scale projects.
Hands-on approach to learning and understanding materials (including wood,
concrete, and stone) and methods in landscape construction, and the
application of technical skills (including detailing, cost estimation, and
specifications).
prereq: LDA 001; LDA 002; LDA 003; LDA 021; LDA 030; LDA 050; LDA 070

name: International Migration
description:
Analysis of worldwide migration patterns, and social scientific theories of
international and transnational migration. Focus in economical, political, and
social impact of immigration and potential for international and regional
cooperation.
prereq: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 004 recommended.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Analytical Mechanic
description:
Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagranges
and Hamiltons equations
prereq:
(PHY 009B C or better, PHY 009C C or better, PHY 009D C or better); (MAT 021D
C or better, MAT 022A C or better, MAT 022B C or better); Or consent of
department for any of the courses.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take

description:

visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Production Lab
description: Laboratory experience in quantity food production and service.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: Partial Diff Equations
description:
Derivation of partial differential equations; separation of variables;
equilibrium solutions and Laplace's equation; Fourier series; method of
characteristics for the one dimensional wave equation. Solution of
nonhomogeneous equations.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Germanic Myth & Saga
description:
Knowledge of German not required. English translation from the Norse Eddas,
the Volsung and Sigurd-Siegfried cycles, and the Gudrun lays; literary
mythology in German Romanticism culminating in Wagner's "total art-work"
concept and The Ring of the Nibelung cycle. May not be counted toward major in
German.

name: Food, Folklore, & Health
description:
Ancient and modern food folklore in relation to health and well-being. Food
safety, organic food, herbalism, food preservation, and nutritional
enhancement.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Real Analysis
description: Metric spaces and multi-variable calculus.

name: Source & Use Acctg Info
description:
Develops an understanding of the supply and demand of accounting information.
Topics include the generation and processing of accounting information, the
examination of accounting information by auditors, and the use of accounting
information by capital markets and tax authorities.
prereq:
MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better; must have C- or better in all
prerequisite courses.

name: Music as Culture
description:
Introduction to the study of music in cross-cultural perspective. Basic
theories and frameworks of ethnomusicology; in-depth case studies of three
musical traditions from around the world. Intended for music majors.

name: Mex Hist Since 1848
description: History of Mexico from 1848 to the present.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Res Method Human Develop
description:
Scientific process, research designs, and experimental controls; APA
manuscript style and scientific writing; statistical analysis and
interpretation of results. Laboratory exercises to collect data, analyze and
interpret results, and write scientific papers.
prereq: STA 013 or STA 013V or STA 013Y or EDU 114 or PSC 041 or (SOC 046A, SOC 046B)

name: Capoeira Ensemble
description:
Basic instrumental techniques, songs, and dance movements of Capoeira Angola.
Protocols of a Capoeira Angola performance and the meanings of Capoeira in
Brazil with its connections to Afro-Brazilian culture.

name: General Microbiology Lab
description:
Principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms.
Designed for students continuing in microbiology, genetics, or biochemistry.
prereq:
MIC 102 C or better; (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 129A); and Consent of
Instructor.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Integration; calculus for trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic
functions; applications.
prereq:
MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better or MAT
021AH C- or better

name: Elementary Italian
description:
Introduction to Italian grammar and development of all language skills in a
cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021B. Sequences, series, tests for convergence, Taylor
expansions. Vector algebra, vector calculus, scalar and vector fields. Partial
derivatives, total differentials. Applications to maximum and minimum problems
in two or more variables. Applications to physical systems.
prereq:
MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better or MAT
021BH C- or better or MAT 017B B or better

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: Humanities Forum
description:
Reading and discussion of a single work representative of a particular
culture, historical period, or genre and significant for its ongoing cultural
impact in the humanities, sciences, social sciences, technology, and popular
arenas. Attention to provocative implications for contemporary society.

name: Adv LA Studio I
description:
Landscape architecture studio featuring advanced studies and applications of
creative work, design, technology and/or theory. One day-long field trip
required.

name: Intro To Philos
description:
Problems of philosophy through major writings from various periods. Problems
are drawn from political, aesthetic, religious, metaphysical, and
epistemological concerns of philosophy.

name: Intro Math Phys
description:
Introduction to the mathematics used in upper division physics courses,
including applications of vector spaces, Fourier analysis, partial
differential equations.
prereq:
(PHY 009B C- or better, PHY 009C C- or better, PHY 009D C- or better); (MAT
021D C- or better, MAT 022A C- or better, MAT 022B C- or better); or Consent
of Instructor.

name: Early Music Ensemble
description:
Rehearsal and performance of Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque music for
vocal ensemble and historical instruments.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Intro to Mil Skills
description:
Personal and organizational leadership skills introduced in leadership
laboratory. Extensive supervised leadership experiences conducted in a
military environment. Basic military skills necessary to function in a
leadership role.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Lower division standing.

name: Intro to Symbol Logic
description:
Syntax and semantics of the symbolic language sentence logic. Symbols of
sentence logic. Translation between sentence logic and English. Truth table
interpretation of sentence logic. Proof techniques. Application of truth
tables and proof techniques to arguments in English.

name: Electronics
description:
Experimental and theoretical study of important analog electronic circuits.
Linear circuits, transmission lines, input impedance, feedback, amplifiers,
oscillators, noise.
prereq: PHY 009C; MAT 022B; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Discov & Concepts
description:
Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts;
properties of nutrients and foods.

name: Systemic Physiology Lab
description:
Selected experiments to illustrate functional characteristics of organ systems
discussed in NPB 101.

name: Curr Topics in Nutrition
description:
Exploration of current applications and controversies in nutrition. Rread
scientific journal articles and write summaries, as well as give brief oral
presentations. Topics change to reflect current interests and issues.

name: Scientific Study War
description:
Analysis of political processes involved in the initiation, conduct and
termination of modern interstate warfare.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Smart Materials Lab
description:
Experimental investigation of electronic, optical and magnetic properties of
engineering materials, emphasizing the fundamental relationship between
microstructure and properties as well as the influence of rate processes on
the evolution of the microstructure and properties.
prereq: EMS 172 { can be concurrent }; Concurrent enrollment in EMS 172 recommended.

name: Language & Society
description:
Language as a social phenomenon. Topics include linguistic diversity, language
policy, language and identity, language and social structure, speech
communities and social networks, the effect of social factors on language
variation, linguistic consequences of language contact.

name: Accel Calculus
description:
Accelerated treatment of material from MAT 021A and MAT 021B, with detailed
presentation of theory, definitions, and proofs, and treatment of
computational aspects of calculus at a condensed but sophisticated level.
prereq:
Grade of B or higher in both semesters of high school calculus or a score of 4
or higher on the Advanced Placement Calculus AB exam, and obtaining the
required score on the Precalculus Diagnostic Examination and its trigonometric
component.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro to GIS
description:
Basic concepts, principles, and methods of GIS are presented. Data structures,
database design, GIS data creation, GPS, and spatial analysis. May be taught
abroad.

name: Intro Elec Music
description:
Basics of electronic music history, techniques, and composition. Fixed media
creation using field recordings. Focus on history, theory and techniques of
musique concrte, elektronische musik, and related repertoire.

name: Honors Physics
description: Electricity and magnetism. Continuation of Physics 9HC.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Int Fin Accounting I
description:
Begin to develop expertise in the accounting for assets and introduce analysis
of financial statements.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Topics Anlys & Theory
description:
Analysis of works of a composer or musical style selected by the instructor
and announced in advance. Consideration of theoretical issues.
prereq: MUS 006C; MUS 024C; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Technology Management
description:
Management of firms in high technology industries such as software development
and biotechnology research. Motivating and managing workers, organizing for
innovation, and making decisions.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Amer Revolution
description:
Analysis of the Revolutionary epoch with emphasis on the structure of British
colonial policy, the rise of revolutionary movements, the War for Independence
and its consequences, and the Confederation period.

name: Field Exp In P E
description:
Tutoring or teachers aide in physical education activities, including athletic
coaching, in public schools under the guidance of a regular teacher with
supervision by a departmental faculty person.
prereq: PHE 001 or PHE 007; Upper division standing.

name: Construction Documents
description:
Legal and professional aspects of landscape architecture, including the
development of construction documents (drawings and specifications), proposal
writing, fee calculations, project management, cost estimation, and insurance.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro Microbiology Lab
description:
Introduction to principles and laboratory methods employed in working with
microorganisms. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional
school admission. May be taught abroad.

name: Complex Variables
description:
Complex number system, analyticity and the Cauchy-Riemann equations,
elementary functions, complex integration, power and Laurent series
expansions, residue theory.

name: Cyborgs & Prostheses
description:
Interface of biology and technology. Mind-controlled prosthetic limbs,
artificial organs, and implantable devices. Emphasis on basic physiological
functions and how they can be replaced by devices. Suitable for majors and
non-majors.

name: Healthful Living
description:
Application of scientific and empirical knowledge to personal, family, and
community health problems.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Intro Environ Plant
description:
Classification, nomenclature and variation of environmental plants. The use of
floral and vegetative characteristics and terminology to key unknown plants.
Characteristics of plant groups and basics of climate, soils and plant
selection. Identification of 150 common landscape plants.

name: Readings in Latin Prose
description:
Review of Latin morphology, grammar, and vocabulary. Readings in prose
authors, including Julius Caesar.

name: Team Leadership
description:
Leadership values, attributes and theories. Use of basic military skills such
as land navigation and squad operations to enhance understanding of the Army.
Types of military briefings. Practice in interpersonal skills. Presentation of
a briefing.
prereq: Lower division standing or consent of instructor.

name: Number Theory
description:
Divisibility and related topics, diophantine equations, selected topics from
the theory of prime numbers. Designed to serve as preparation for the more
rigorous upper division courses.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Number Theory
description:
Divisibility and related topics, diophantine equations, selected topics from
the theory of prime numbers. Designed to serve as preparation for the more
rigorous upper division courses.

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: Scientific Reason
description:
Introduction to scientific hypotheses and the kinds of reasoning used to
justify such hypotheses. Emphasis on adequate justification, criteria, and
strategies for distinguishing scientific from pseudoscientific theories.
Concrete historical and contemporary cases.

name: Early Lit In Engl
description:
Study of early Japanese literature from the Nara to the end of the Heian
period through a broad survey of the major literary genres such as lyric
poetry, court diaries, prose narratives, poem-tales, and classical Chinese
writings.

name: Shifa Clinic
description:
Attend clinic every third Sunday performing duties of receptionist, intake,
translation, monitor. Students attend a meeting immediately after end of
clinic. There is a mandatory Monday meeting with Clinic co-directors. Students
are expected to participate on various committees.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. The applications will be available for students.
Selection of students will be made by selection committee of medical students
coordinators and the IOR.

name: Internship Pub Aff
description:
Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related
organizations.
prereq:
Enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions with highest priority
assigned to students with Political Science Public Service major; upper
division standing.

name: General Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for
students majoring in a biological science.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Land Rep I
description:
Introduction to landscape architectural representation techniques.
Fundamentals of orthographic drafting, freehand drawing, photography, and
basic digital representation.
prereq: LDA 001 { can be concurrent }; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: History of Rock Music
description:
Rock and the evolution of rock styles in historical and cultural context. For
non-majors.

name: Intro Music Lit
description:
Introduction to composers and major styles of Western music. Lectures,
listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

name: Env Tox Air Pollutants
description:
Field trip required. Toxicology of air pollutants in the ambient, indoor, and
occupational environments. Health effects, sources, environmental fates,
pulmonary responses, sampling and analyses, and air-quality criteria and
standards. Field trip required.
prereq: CHE 008B { can be concurrent }; Or the equivalent; BIS 102 recommended.

name: Intro Global Disease Bio
description:
Introduction to the Global Disease Biology major, research and internship
opportunities, and potential career paths in human, animal, and plant health.
Communication, ethics and the nature of science.
prereq: Open to GDB majors only, or Consent of Instructor.

name: Adv LA Studio I
description:
Landscape architecture studio featuring advanced studies and applications of
creative work, design, technology and/or theory. One day-long field trip
required.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Scientific Reason
description:
Introduction to scientific hypotheses and the kinds of reasoning used to
justify such hypotheses. Emphasis on adequate justification, criteria, and
strategies for distinguishing scientific from pseudoscientific theories.
Concrete historical and contemporary cases.

name: US in the 1960s
description:
Tumult and upheaval in American politics, culture, and society 1961-1969.
Civil rights; Vietnam, the draft and the anti-war movement; rock and roll and
the counterculture; modern feminism; modern conservatism; student movements;
urban unrest and insurrection.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Developmental Psychology
description:
Ontogenetic account of human behavior through adolescence with emphasis on
motor skills, mental abilities, motivation, and social interaction.

name: Indig & Minority Langs
description:
Survey of the status of indigenous, immigrant, and other minority languages in
the Americas and around the world. Topics include linguistic diversity,
language endangerment & revitalization, heritage language maintenance in
immigrant communities, and language change due to transcultural interactions.

name: Wrkshp in Composition
description:
Workshop in musical composition for undergraduates who are interested in
pursuing serious compositional studies and intending to follow the composition
track of the major. Explores the techniques and materials of musical
composition.

name: University Symphony
description:
Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements
of concert performance. Sight-reading, rehearsal and performance of music from
the orchestral literature.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: University Concert Band
description: Rehearsal and performance of music for band.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Elementary Italian
description:
Introduction to Italian grammar and development of all language skills in a
cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

name: Analytical Mechanic
instructor: Manuel Calderon De La Barca Sanchez
description:
Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagranges
and Hamiltons equations
prereq:
(PHY 009B C or better, PHY 009C C or better, PHY 009D C or better); (MAT 021D
C or better, MAT 022A C or better, MAT 022B C or better); Or consent of
department for any of the courses.

name: Computers in Technology
description:
Concepts of computing and applications using personal computers, spreadsheets,
database management, word processing and communications.

name: Classical Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for
physical science and engineering majors. Classical mechanics.
prereq: MAT 021B or MAT 021M; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Tutor Plant Sciences
description:
Leading small voluntary discussion or lab groups affiliated with one of the
department's regular courses.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing, completion of course being
tutored or the equivalent.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Combinatorics
description:
Combinatorial methods using basic graph theory, counting methods, generating
functions, and recurrence relations. Designed to serve as preparation for the
more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Intl Relations
description:
Analysis and evaluation of substantive issues in contemporary international
relations. Readings drawn from current academic and non-academic periodicals.
May be taught abroad.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Computational Linguistic
description:
Understanding the nature of language through computer modeling of linguistic
abilities. Relationships between human cognition and computer representations
of cognitive processing.

name: First Year Engagement
description:
Introduction to university life. Topics include transition to academic and
campus life; academic expectations and the skills to meet them; campus
resources; social and professional development; assistance in choice of major,
and academic planning.

name: Trees & Forests
description:
Biological structure and function of trees as organisms; understanding of
forests as communities and as ecosystems; use of forests by humans; tree
phenology, photosynthesis, respiration, soil processes, life histories,
dormancy, forest biodiversity, and agroforestry.

name: Cognitive Development
description:
Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive
development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of
plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and
social world, and language.

name: Tutoring
description:
Assisting the instructor by tutoring students in one of the Department's
regular courses.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: General Physics
description: Continuation of PHY 007B.

name: Voice
description: Individual instruction in voice.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Aesthetics
description:
Nature of art, of artistic creation, of the work of art, and of aesthetic
experience; nature and validity of criticism; relations of art to its
environment.

name: Plant Physiology
description:
Plant cell as a functional unit. The processes of absorption, movement, and
utilization of water and minerals. Water loss, translocation, photosynthesis,
respiration.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); (CHE 008B { can be concurrent } or CHE 118B {
can be concurrent }); PHY 007C { can be concurrent }; PLB 105 recommended.

name: Psych of Music
description:
Introduction to the mental and neural representations of musical structures
and processes involved in perceiving, remembering, and performing music. Music
and emotion.
prereq:
(PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 100 or PSC 135 or MUS 006C); or Consent
of Instructor.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: Supply Chain Management
description:
Develops key concepts and relationships between supply chain design and
business models and strategies. Much of the focus is on quantitative
techniques for analysis & management of the production and delivery of goods &
services by an organization.

name: Elementary Latin
description:
Introduction to basic grammar and vocabulary and development of translation
skills with emphasis on Latin to English.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Circuits I
description:
Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities
and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC
circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network
functions.

name: Modern Japanese
description:
Readings in modern Japanese short stories, newspaper articles, and essays;
conversation practice based on these readings.
prereq: JPN 006 C- or better; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: Intro Music Theory Pt 1
description:
Fundamentals of music theory, ear-training, harmony, counterpoint, and
analysis directed toward the development of listening and writing techniques.
Intended for the general student.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Evol Ecol Syst
description:
Evolution as an organizing force in natural communities. Coadaptation in
trophic and competitive relationships. Ecology of polymorphisms, clines, and
speciation.
prereq: (EVE 101 or ESP 100); EVE 100; Or equivalent courses.

name: Applied Linear Algebra
description:
Applications of linear algebra; LU and QR matrix factorizations, eigenvalue
and singular value matrix decompositions.

name: First Year Engagement
description:
Introduction to university life. Topics include transition to academic and
campus life; academic expectations and the skills to meet them; campus
resources; social and professional development; assistance in choice of major,
and academic planning.

name: African American Music
description:
Survey of African American music, such as spirituals, blues, ragtime, jazz,
theater, gospel, R&B;, rap, and art music. Emphasis on historical and
sociocultural contexts, as well as African roots.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Introductory Mycology
description:
Systematics, ecology, evolution, and morphology of fungi. Importance of fungi
to humans.

name: Issues in Humanities
description: Small group discussions and preparation of short papers for HUM 001.
prereq: HUM 001 { can be concurrent }; HUM 001 required concurrently.

name: Classical Physics
description:
Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena,
optics.
prereq: PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D { can be concurrent }

name: Neurobiology Foundations
description:
Core concepts of neurobiology including single-neuron biophysics, synapses and
transmitters, neuronal development, motor systems, central pattern generation,
neuronal circuits, intracellular signal transduction, sensory processing,
multisensory integration, autonomic nervous system, neuromodulation, learning
and memory, and higher cognition and disease.
prereq: NPB 110A C- or better; PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Modern Physics
description:
Introduction to physics concepts developed since 1900. Special relativity,
quantum mechanics, atoms, molecules, condensed matter, nuclear and particle
physics.
prereq: PHY 009C; MAT 022A; MAT 022B recommended (may be taken concurrently).

name: Computationl Lab Phyiscs
instructor: Manuel Calderon De La Barca Sanchez
description:
Introduction to computational physics and to the computational resources in
the physics department. Preparation for brief programming assignments required
in other upper division physics classes.
prereq:
MAT 021D; ECS 030; (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD); PHY 104A { can be concurrent };
MAT 22AB; PHY 104A required concurrently.

name: Measurement Systems
description:
Experiments to illustrate principles of mechanical systems. Signal analysis;
Demonstration of basic sensors for mechanical systems; Experimental project
design; Experiments involving voltage measurement; strain gauges, dynamic
systems of 1st order.
prereq: ENG 100 C- or better; ENG 102 C- or better; ENG 104 recommended.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro To NAS
description:
Introduction to Native American Studies with emphasis upon basic concepts
relating to Native American historical and political development.

name: Molecules to Individuals
description:
Major concepts in cell biology with special emphasis on connections between
cell biology and behavior. Includes: cellular metabolism, cellular sensing and
signaling, membrane structure-function, molecular switches, electrical and
chemical signaling, endocrine signaling, cell cycle and differentiation,
cytoskeleton, and integrative examples. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B); (CHE 002B or CHE 003A); PHY 007A and PHY 007B
recommended; BIS 002C recommended.

name: PE Internship
description:
Work experience in the application of physical activity programs to teaching,
recreational, clinical or research situations under department faculty
supervision.
prereq:
Upper division standing and consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on
availability of intern positions, with priority given to Exercise Science
majors.

name: Chicano Politics
description:
Political aspects of Chicano life in America; examines the Chicano's political
role as it has been historically defined by different groups in society and
the Chicano's responses to his/her political environment.

name: General Psychology
description:
Introduction to empirical approaches. Focus on perception, cognition,
personality and social psychology, and biological aspects of behavior.

name: General Physics
description: Continuation of PHY 007A.

name: Laboratory Research
description:
Training in specific lab-based research methods coupled with hands-on
experience in a research lab. Students assessed on their ability report and
interpret research findings. Content varies from quarter to quarter.

name: Plant Ecology
description:
The study of the interactions between plants, plant populations or vegetation
types and their physical and biological environment. Special emphasis on
California. Four full-day field trips and brief write-up of class project
required.
prereq:
(BIS 001A, BIS 001B, BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); PLB 111
recommended.

name: Health Psychology
description:
Psychological factors influencing health and illness. Topics include stress
and coping, personality and health, symptom perception and reporting, heart
disease, cancer, compliance, and health maintenance and promotion.

name: Intro to Public Health
description:
Provide basic concepts and controversies in public health, basic science of
public health, social and behavioral factors in health and disease,
environmental and occupational health issues, the relationship of public
health to the medical care system and health care reform.

name: Plant Metabolic Process
description:
Principles of energy capture and photosynthesis, water use, and nutrient
cycling. Conversion of these resources into products (carbohydrates, proteins,
lipids, and other chemicals) by plants. Emphasis on the relationships between
environmental resources, plant metabolism and plant growth.
prereq: PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Intermed Japanese
description:
Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural
context, based on language skills developed in JPN 003.
prereq: JPN 003 C- or better; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: Critical Reasoning
description:
Criteria of good reasoning in everyday life and in science. Topics to be
covered may include basic principles of deduction and induction; fallacies in
reasoning; techniques and aids to reasoning; principles of scientific
investigation; aids to clarity.

name: Prof Act Men & Wom
description:
Fundamental skills for: (a) coaching competitive athletics; (b) classroom
teaching and coaching, and (c) classroom teaching and officiating.

name: Plants & Society
description:
Dependence of human societies on plant and plant products. Plants as resources
for food, fiber, health, enjoyment and environmental services. Sustainable
uses of plants for food production, raw materials, bioenergy, and
environmental conservation. Global population growth and future food supplies.

name: Physics Careers
description:
Overview of important research areas in physics, discussions of research
opportunities and internships, strategies for graduate school and industrial
careers, the fellowship and assistantship selection process, preparation of
resumes, personal statements, and letters of recommendation.

name: When Institutions Fail
description:
Examination of factors contributing to the success and failure of political
institutions.

name: West European Politics
description:
Evolution, politics, and contemporary problems of selected political systems
of Western Europe. May be taught abroad.

name: The Oceans
description:
Introductory survey of the marine environment. Oceanic physical phenomena,
chemical constituents and chemistry of water, geological history, the seas
biota and human utilization of marine resources

name: Elementary Latin
description:
Introduction to basic grammar and vocabulary and development of translation
skills with emphasis on Latin to English.

name: Numerical Analysis
description:
Error analysis, approximation, interpolation, numerical differentiation and
integration. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC
required.
prereq: MAT 021C; (ECS 032A or ENG 006 or EME 005 or ECS 030)

name: General Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for
students majoring in a biological science.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Fruit & Nut Crop Systems
description:
Overview of production and handling systems of major pomological crops,
analysis of current cultural and harvesting problems and concerns associated
with commercial fruit growing.
prereq: PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Systemic Physiology Disc
description:
Discussion and problem solving related to fundamental principles of systemic
physiology as presented in NPB 101.
prereq: NPB 101 { can be concurrent }; Consent of Instructor.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Applied Stat in Ag Sci
description:
Application of statistical methods to design and analysis of research trials
for plant, animal, behavioral, nutritional, and consumer sciences. Basic
concepts and statistical methods are presented in lectures, laboratories
emphasize data processing techniques, problem solving, and interpretation in
specialized fields.

name: Internship
description:
Work experience on or off campus in subject areas pertaining to plant and
environmental sciences. Internship supervised by a faculty member.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Completion of 84 units.

name: Introductory Mycology
description:
Systematics, ecology, evolution, and morphology of fungi. Importance of fungi
to humans.

name: Criminology
description:
Sociological analysis of criminal behavior in relation to social structure and
the criminalization process.

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including corporations,
government agencies, and non-profit. Suitable for students entering careers
such as management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Hmn Wrgs/Hmn Rights
description:
Introduction to Human Rights and the problems they seek to address. Using key
episodes of inhumanity like slavery, genocide, and racism. Examines how
international movements for social justice led to the emergence of the
international Human Rights system.

name: Intermediate Theory
description:
Homophonic music of the Classical era with a focus on analysis of music by
Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven. Composition of pieces in the homophonic forms
such as minuet and trio, theme and variations, rondo and sonata. Intended for
music majors.

name: Expt in Nutrition
description:
Experiments in current nutritional problems. Experimental design:students
choose project and, independently or in groups of two-three, design a
protocol, complete the project, and report findings.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. NUT 111AV, NUT 111AY, NUT 111B or NUT 114 recommended.

name: Cardio-Respir-Renal
description:
Intense and advanced presentation of concepts in cardiovascular, respiratory,
and renal physiology including discussion of acid-base balance.
prereq: (NPB 110C or NPB 101); CHE 008B, PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.

name: Constitutional Politics
description:
Constitutional politics surrounding such issues as the right to free
expression, associational rights, the right to free exercise of religious
beliefs and the right to privacy.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Human Brain & Disease
description:
Normal function and diseases of the human brain and nervous system. Diseases
discussed include Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, leprosy, amnesia and
schizophrenia. Intended for non-science majors.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: A Priori Knowledge
description:
Self-evidence, intuition, the (in)fallibility and (in)defeasibility of a
priori methods. Analytic, formalist and Kantian accounts of how knowledge can
be acquired through reasoning and intuition alone, without recourse to
empirical methods.

name: Philosophy Of Mind
description:
The relation between mind and body, our knowledge of other minds, and the
explanation of mental acts. Discussion of such concepts as action, intention,
and causation.

name: Elementary Latin
description:
Introduction to basic grammar and vocabulary and development of translation
skills with emphasis on Latin to English.

name: Intro Undergrad Research
description: The nature of research at the undergraduate level.
prereq:
IST 009; consent of instructor; completion of 45 units with a minimum GPA of
3.500.

name: Animal Behavior
description:
Basic principles of behavioral organization in vertebrate and invertebrate
animals. Underlying physiological and ethological mechanisms. The evolution of
behavior, with special emphasis on behavior under natural conditions.

name: Minds Brains Comp w/Disc
description:
